name: Carlitz–Wan conjecture
summary: The Carlitz–Wan conjecture is a theorem in finite field theory that states there are no exceptional polynomials of degree \(d\) over a finite field \(F_{q}\) if the greatest common divisor of \(d\) and \(q-1\) is greater than 1 (i.e., \(\text{gcd}(d,q-1)>1\)). In simpler terms, it provides conditions under which a polynomial cannot be "exceptional," which is a polynomial that acts as a permutation on infinitely many finite field extensions of \(F_{q}\). This conjecture was originally proposed by Leonard Carlitz in 1966, generalized by Daqing Wan in 1993, and proven by Hendrik Lenstra in 1995.
head: a polynomial is a "permutation polynomial" (meaning it shuffles the elements of the finite field \(F_{q}\))
tail: its degree \(n\) and the value \(q-1\) must be "coprime" (their greatest common divisor is 1)
